div.p: FROM Le Philoſophe Mariè of M. N. Deſtouches.
AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL, HAYMARKET, AND THE NEW THEATRE, PHILADELPHIA.

div.head: SCENE I. A library at SIR JOHN CLASSICK's.
div.stage: SIR JOHN diſcovered at a table, muſing.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: A ſcholar, a philoſopher, to change his peaceful hours, his nights of ſtudy, and his days of fame!— And for what?—A wife!—A wife without a fortune too!—Where was my wiſdom?—But young and handſome!—Where was my philoſophy?—Where my pride, to do an act at which I bluſh?— [After ſighing heavily, and ſhewing evident ſigns of uneaſineſs, he takes a book and begins to read—Dorimant enters unperceived by ſir John, and ſeats himſelf at the table.]

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: [Laying down the book.] Ah! Dorimant, my friend, it is you I have to blame—You were the cauſe of my marriage—you painted wedlock with an eloquence that deluded me—Pictured my wife as ſoft, complying—

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: And is not ſhe?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: [Starting.] You there!—Why do you ſteal upon me thus?

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: Steal upon you!—Were you not talking to me?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: Then you were guilty of very ungentelmanly-like behaviour, to abuſe me when you did not know I was preſent to defend myſelf. And ſuppoſe I adviſed you to marry; did not you aſk my advice?— Were you not charmed when I gave my advice?—Beſides, is it poſſible you can repent?—With what on earth have you to reproach your wife?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Her indiſcretion—which keeps me in perpetual torture.—She knows how much I feel on the occaſion, and how earneſtly I have entreated our marriage might be kept ſecret; and yet it is her firſt pleaſure the world ſhould know ſhe has a huſband—and that I am the unfortunate man.

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: I can eaſily imagine your deſire has not been ſtrictly complied with—but you could not, ſurely, think to be married half your life without having it ſometime or other known in the world.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: A ſecret alliance, formed near two years ago, without my father's conſent or knowledge, would expoſe me to his juſt reſentment.

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: His reſentment will be eaſily overcome —for his obligations to you are ſo great—his affection for you ſo tender—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: That I fear his ſorrow, much more than his anger.—But there is another reaſon.

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: That, indeed, has ſome weight; for you mean your uncle, the old rich contractor, whoſe obſtinacy and inhumanity, if he knew you had married a lady with a fortune unequal to that he means to give you, might cauſe him never perhaps to give you a ſhilling.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: And, beſide theſe, I have another reaſon yet; one, which (to my own feelings) is of more conſequence than any.—You know I have always made a jeſt of matrimony, laughed at, and ridiculed all huſbands; I am therefore now aſhamed, and bluſh at the title—There is ſomething in marriage that takes from the dignity—

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p:
Will it take from the dignity of knighthood, which you have gained by your learned diſſertations?
No; nor can there be any reaſon but your uncle's diſpleaſure why it ſhould be any longer concealed. Certainly you muſt pay ſome attention to that; and it ought to be a weighty conſideration with your lady.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: So it is, I dare ſay—but the pleaſure of telling a ſecret weighs heavier far.—After all, ſhe is not the only one who takes pleaſure in propagating the news—her ſiſter, to whom you deſign yourſelf the happy huſband, has whiſpered the ſecret to moſt of her acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: I am vext at ſuch indiſcretion, and will go to both ladies inſtantly with my complaint— [Going, returns.] And now do you apply yourſelf to ſtudy— and employ all your knowledge to obtain that degree of patience requiſite to your ſtate.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: And do you furniſh yourſelf with ample ſtore againſt you marry my ſiſter-in-law; for, by Heaven, you will want it all.

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: I know Emily well—know all her faults —But love them all—even that pride which diſdains me I approve; for while my unfortunate quarrel conceals from her my real name and family, ſhe is right in treating me ſo lightly.—Yet that ſhe loves me, I am convinced; and, the moment my antagoniſt is pronounced out of danger, I will ſilence every ſcruple, by revealing to her, that, inſtead of poor Dorimant, who has no other friend upon earth but you, I have a fortune and family as much above hers, as ſhe now believes hers is above mine.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Oh! I long to ſee you a huſband—How miſchievous does ill luck make a man! I have not one acquaintance at this moment that I do not wiſh to ſee married!
sp.stage: [He ſits down and begins to read.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: [Looking at ſir John.] Always reading! And never thinking of his wife day nor night. [Aſide.] —Sir, ſir, her ladyſhip deſired me to come—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: "Her ladyſhip"—Do ſpeak a little louder—

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Her ladyſhip. Lady Claſſick.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: [Starting up.] Silence!—I thought, mrs. Lucy, I had a hundred times forbidden you to make uſe of that name.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, ſir—but when one forgets, I can't ſee what harm it can do.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: You know you were amongſt the few who were entruſted with the ſecret of our marriage.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: And I have kept it a ſecret theſe two years! —Two years is a long time to hold one's tongue.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But do you know what I may forfeit by your indiſcretion—the wealth of which the diſpleaſure of my uncle may deprive me?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: I thought philoſophers deſpiſed all ſuch dirty droſs as gold.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But, mrs. Lucy, although I may be of that opinion, perhaps my children may not, and I may one day be reproached for neglecting their fortunes.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: But, ſir, your children are yet to come, and a philoſopher's talent is to reform the world, but very ſeldom to people it.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Entruſting you with a ſecret, mrs. Lucy, has given you a freedom that may very ſoon loſe you your place.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Oh, ſir! I am ſure you know better than to turn a ſervant away, whom you have been obliged to truſt with a ſecret.—There are many better ways to keep a ſervant ſilent.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: And this I ſuppoſe is one?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, ſir—and now I'll be ſilent for a month —and if you repeat this, at the end of that month, I'll be ſilent for the next—and ſo on. But, ſir, I had almoſt forgot my errand—her ladyſhip—no—my miſtreſs —not her ladyſhip—not your wife—but my miſtreſs— ſent me to aſk if you will permit her to wait upon you here—as ſhe has ſomething particular to ſpeak to you about.—Oh! ſhe is here, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Have I not deſired you a thouſand times, madam, not to follow me here?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And I have as many times obeyed you—but at preſent I want to ſpeak to you on a ſubject of ſo much importance, to us both, that I have ventured to diſobey your commands.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: "Commands!"—You talk to me as if I were your tyrant.—I have but one command—Keep our marriage ſecret.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: To keep it an entire ſecret is impoſſible; our living ſo long together, in the ſame houſe, though on a pretended viſit to the miſtreſs of it, is enough to create ſuſpicion—The world has curioſity, and penetration.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: And has no longer any doubt but we are man and wife.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Indeed!—Do they really think ſo?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Yes—and I fear, ſay ſo too.—Why theſe expreſſions of joy?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: To have you for a huſband is a happineſs ſo flattering—a felicity of which I feel myſelf ſo proud— that to have it known, would give me infinite delight.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: In contradiction to my will?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: —Perhaps the deſire is wrong—but if it be my fault (I muſt own) it would conſtitute my greateſt happineſs.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: A woman's eloquence is irreſiſtible. [Aſide.] But did not you promiſe me that your ſiſter and your woman ſhould be the only perſons to whom you would confide this ſecret?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And you ſhould accuſe my ſiſter, not me—It is ſhe who has forfeited her word, not I.—I have kept mine but too well. Yet though by the concealment my reputation may be wounded, I ſubmit without complaint—But, if I make this ſacrifice to you, ſuffer me to demand a ſmall one in return.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: That lord Lovemore, either by you or by me, may be made acquainted with our marriage.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: The very perſon of all the world I would moſt conceal it from; for to him more frequently than to any other perſon, have I declared my ſentiments of the marriage ſtate; and in what a deſpicable light, to him, muſt my inconſiſtency appear?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No—notwithſtanding you are married, neither his lordſhip, nor any other perſon, moſt intimately acquainted with your former ſentiments, can accuſe you of inconſiſtency.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Did I not rail at marriage?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Do you not now?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But had I not an utter averſion to it?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And have you not now?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But why ſhould you be uneaſy at that? I love you—and ſhould like you better, if you were any thing but my wife.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And being my huſband, I love you far better than if you were any thing on earth beſide.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I will not have our marriage declared to any one.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Yes! to lord Lovemore—you muſt conſent.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: From what motive?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Excuſe me—but be aſſured it is indiſpenſible; and why have you ſuch a particular apprehenſion of him; for although this lord is a fine gentleman, and in high eſteem with the gay world, yet I have frequently heard you ſpeak but ſlightly of his underſtanding?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Therefore I fear him—you know I always fear a fool—It is the fool, who laughs at the faults of wiſe men, becauſe they are ſo unlike his own. 'Tis the fool who traduces their character—'Tis the fool who ſtops at no means to accompliſh his evil wiſhes. —Fools dreſs to ſeduce women; liſp, chat, flutter, and even lie to win them.—'Tis fools, with whom men of ſenſe cannot ſubmit to quarrel, but muſt fall, like a poor female, by their ſlander.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Why then this fool, in one reſpect, has ſhewn himſelf like you; for he never pays a viſit to this houſe, that he does not immediately come to my apartments to
make the ſame declarations of love, and the ſame offer of his hand and heart, you once did.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: [Starting.] To you?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: To me.—I once thought to keep it a ſecret. —But—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But that was impoſſible?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Yes—for the increaſing ardour of his addreſſes makes it impoſſible to ſubmit to the painful ſituation any longer—and ſurely there is no method ſo effectually and ſo delicately to put an end to his purſuit, as to declare I am your wife. [Sir John ſtarts.] At preſent I will not urge you for a deciſive anſwer—but leave you to reflect upon it.
sp.stage: [Bows, with a tender humility, and retires.]

div.stage: [He ſits down to write as before, then ſtarts from his ſeat and throws the book down in a paſſion.]

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: No—all my ſtudy is at an end for this day—my mind wholly diſſipated with domeſtic concerns—It is impoſſible for a married man to be a philoſopher—and yet it is a ſtate that requires more philoſophy than any other.

div.head: SCENE II. Another apartment of SIR JOHN's.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Has lord Lovemore called this morning?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, madam.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Do you think he likes me?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: No, madam.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: But, I am determined to make him—and you know I will, if I ſay I will.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: And if you ſhould, what then?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Then I ſhall have the pleaſure to tell him I deſpiſe him, and that his title, birth, and fortune could not recompenſe me for a man who had previouſly offered himſelf, and been refuſed by my ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: And I cannot help thinking he loves her ſtill.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p:
As much as a beau, who loves nothing ſo
well as himſelf, can love; and therefore it has long been my deſign to whiſper to him, ſhe is married.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Do you ſuppoſe he will love her the leſs for that?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: His love being but a mere compound of vanity and gallantry, I ſhould ſuppoſe not—but at leaſt the news will mortify his pride—And why ſhould not other people meet with mortifications, as well as I, Lucy?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: And I am ſure, madam, it is not your fault if they do not—for you are ever doing all you can to teaſe every body you know.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: If I could pleaſe them I ſhould be equally content—but as in that my endeavours are moſtly rejected, the only alternative I have to preſerve me from idleneſs is to be miſchievous.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Nay, madam, do not ſay you pleaſe no one; conſider mr. Dorimant.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: And him I have no deſire to pleaſe; for it is to my diſadvantage we ſhould be charmed with each other.—This is the hour he generally calls—Now, Lucy, do ſomething to put me out of humour, that I may break with him at once—Come, talk on ſome ſubject to vex me—ſpeak of my ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Ay, my miſtreſs—the philoſopher ſeems to have loſt all his affection for her.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Pſhaw! you know this pleaſes me—for it in ſome degree extinguiſhes that ſurprize I feel, while I cannot diſcover by what art ſhe gained poſſeſſion of a man of ſenſe, of renown, in ſhort, of ſuch a man as ſir John.—If he were my huſband—as you know I wiſhed him to be—I ſhould have expected him to love me—but to have a tenderneſs for my ſiſter!— [Angrily.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: And I ſtill believe he has, in his heart, a moſt affectionate one.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Do you ſee Dorimant coming?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: That you try to provoke me.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes—as I live—here he is.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p:
I thank you then—for you have left me in
excellent humour.
sp.stage: [Exit Lucy.—Emily ſits down, and appears meditating.

div.stage: Enter DORIMANT, who looks at her ſome time, while ſhe pretends not to ſee him.

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: You wiſh to be alone, I perceive. [He waits for an anſwer, then goes on.] But although I may diſturb you, I cannot forbear—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Being very impertinent.

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: So, ſo—I muſt be all ſubmiſſion, I find.

div.stage: [He moves to a corner of the room, and ſits down, affecting a ſilent dejection.]

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: (After a pauſe.) I deſire you will leave me inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: Certainly—I will [riſing] but condeſcend to tell me wherefore—for if my affectionate ardour—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: "If my affectionate ardour!"—What romantic language!—You treat me as if I were a child.

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: But I know you are very far from one.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: Yes—nothing like a child.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: This ſneer is inſufferable.—I tell you what, Dorimant, I wiſh to hate you—for indeed you have ſo many imperfections—

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: What are they?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Oh, innumerable!—You are vain of your perſon—aſhamed of your birth—ſubmiſſive to your enemies—inſincere to your friends—with a thouſand worſe faults; and yet, with them all—I can't help liking you.

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: As you call my ſincerity in queſtion, I will give you a proof of it immediately—You are haughty, envious, peeviſh, conceited, capricious, imprudent—with a thouſand faults, and yet with them all—"I can't help liking you."

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: No man ſhall marry me who does not think me perfect.

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: That reſolution will not exclude me.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: No?—

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: No—for I think you a perfect woman

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: But you ſhall believe I have not one fault. Go, ſir, leave me—yonder comes my ſiſter, and I am tired of your company.

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: I am all obedience, to ſhew you how you muſt hereafter behave to me.
sp.stage: [Exit on one ſide— Lady Claſſick enters on the other.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: How dare he to ſee one fault in me?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Dear ſiſter, would you have poor Dorimant blind?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Why not, as well as ſir John, when he married?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You think he was.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: But don't miſtake me—I believe his eyes are open now.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Not to the charms of every one who may wiſh to captivate h ••

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Is there any ſuch perſon?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I have heard ſo.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Before his marriage there might be, becauſe the ladies all imagined he would be a difficult conqueſt—But after being ſo eaſily caught, I don't think there is a woman in the world would be at the trouble of conquering him a ſecond time.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: It would be a trouble, I believe.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Without any reward.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: True—for all the honour he can confer, he has beſtowed on me.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: And beſtowed ſo much—he has given up all his own.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Emily, I have too long borne with theſe unkind inſinuations—Reflections caſt upon myſelf I can forgive, but when you make theſe attacks upon ſir John—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: The truth is ſo glaring, you can't bear it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: My dear ſiſter, we will not remain here together, thus eternally to diſpute—either you or I will fix upon ſome other abode.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Oh! ſir John, I am going away—you are juſt come in time to take your leave—I am deſired to quit your houſe inſtantly—your wife—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Don't let me hear that name.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Why this delicacy—when my anxiety to tell you—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: If you have the affection of a huſband—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I won't hear that name.—What is all this?—What do you both want to tell me?—What nonſenſe?—You have had a quarrel, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Nonſenſe!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Nonſenſe—I ſhould not have thought of that!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You muſt know, my dear—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I won't be called my dear.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why then, ſir John—My ſiſter has behaved—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: No—my ſiſter has behaved—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Oh! you have both behaved, I dare ſay.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Your indifference is unkind.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Every thing is indifferent to him, but what is written in a book.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I think ſo.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Look there now—they are going to quarrel with me.—But come, compoſe yourſelves—and tell me, Matilda, how this affair between your ſiſter and you began.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Aſk her.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: No—tell it yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: [After conſidering.] I don't remember how it began.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: [After conſidering.] Nor I either.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p:
The fact is, you have both been quarreling,
and neither of you can tell why.—But pray do not let me interrupt you—for nothing is ſo entertaining to me as to hear ladies diſagree.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Then you ſhall not be entertained at our expence, for we will inſtantly forgive each other.— Siſter, I pardon you ſincerely.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And I am ſure I pardon you.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: And do ſhake hands, to be revenged on me.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And with mine.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: And to ſhew how angry I am, I'll kiſs you both.

div.stage: MR. TRADEWELL CLASSICK enters during the time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: Well employed, upon my word, nephew.
sp.stage: Sir John ſtarts—and the ladies exeunt in confuſion.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: [Aſide.] My uncle—Confuſion!

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: I am ſorry I ſhould intrude upon your private ſtudies.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: A philoſopher, I find, is but a human creature after all!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Dear ſir—theſe ladies you ſaw here— are—

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: [Aſide.] I don't know what to ſay.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: Finiſh your ſentence—Speak— What are they?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: They are [heſitating]—ſiſters.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: Well—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: [Heſitating.] From the country—and as they are going into the country again—I was taking my leave of them—as you ſaw.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: But what brought them here?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: A mere accident.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p:
I don't like accidents, when women are in the eaſe—They are the cauſe of many unlucky
accidents—and I would have nothing impede the buſineſs upon which I came to ſpeak to you.—I have procured you a wife—I know you have pretended an averſion to matrimony—but that was merely to ſome of its forms, and in this caſe ſomething more ſubſtantial is to be attended to; the lady I have choſen is young, handſome, and, above all, very rich; and ſome family reaſons will make it neceſſary the marriage ſhould take place within a few days.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Deſtruction [Aſide]—But who is the lady, ſir?—Perhaps—

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: There is no perhaps—for ſhe is my daughter-in-law—my wife's only child—and with a fortune—You don't ſeem pleaſed—Let me tell you, the lady muſt not be deſpiſed.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Deſpiſed, ſir!—No, no—but—

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: No buts, ſir—You have written againſt matrimony to make your book ſell—So far you did right—I would write againſt it myſelf if I could get any thing by it.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But, ſir—

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: My pockets are filled with parchments—follow me into your library, there we will look them over, and take care there's no cheating, unleſs it ſhould be on our ſide—follow me, for I am growing old, and not ſo expert at thoſe things as I uſed to be.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Sir, lord Lovemore called to tell you he will dine with you to day.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: More good news; [Aſide.] ſend to him, and let him know—

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: We need not ſend to him, ſir, he is here.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Here!—Where is he?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: With my miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: More good news.— [Aſide.] Let him know my uncle is unexpectedly arrived—I cannot come to him juſt now—but in about half an hour—

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Oh! you need make no apology, ſir—he won't think the time long.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: No—as he is with my miſtreſs, he won't mind waiting—he'll not be impatient—you need not hurry yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: If that's the caſe, I ſhall hurry myſelf.

div.stage: [Exit, in haſte, on the oppoſite ſide to where he was going.

div.head: SCENE I. Another apartment at SIR JOHN's—LORD LOVERULE, SIR JOHN and LADY diſcovered.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: My dear ſir John, I excuſe you moſt willingly, for I know how much depends upon your pleaſing the old contractor, and how difficult it is to pleaſe him.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: And in one thing he has juſt propoſed, I fear it will prove impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: He has choſen me a wife, and wants me to marry immediately.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: You marry—you—ha, ha, ha, ha—does he know your reſolution?—does he know that you would not marry the fineſt woman in the world?— [Sir John ſhews evident ſigns of uneaſineſs.]—to marry would make you the laughing-ſtock of the whole town—You, that have laughed at every married man!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: [Uneaſy.] They don't make me laugh ſo much as they did.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: No—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: No—but I think I pity them more than I did.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: And does your old uncle imagine he can prevail upon you to quit a bachelor's life?—impoſſible— and yet, would you believe it, there are ſome people in this town credulous enough to report you are married —but I take care to vindicate your character,

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Thank you—I am very much obliged to you.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p:
No, ſir John, I never will ſtand ſilently by, and hear your firmneſs of temper called in queſtion— the lady [bowing to lady C.] I tell them, may have charms to captivate the coldeſt heart, yet between her and ſir John, I am poſitive no other than a ſincere
friendſhip ſubſiſts; for he himſelf has told me ſo a hundred times.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe I have—to be ſure—you are quite right.
sp.stage: [He makes ſigns to lady C. who appears anxious to ſpeak, to be ſilent.]

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: And now, my dear ſir John, as I know you to be not only her friend, but mine, permit me to repeat, in your preſence, what in private I have a thouſand times uttered.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: And as a friend to us both, exert your friendſhip for both our happineſs—for if my eſteem, my love, my adoration of you, beautiful Matilda— [ſeizing her hand.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir John—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Nay, do not frown upon the man who doats upon you to diſtraction.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: [Aſide.] I make a very reſpectable figure here.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: But receive my vows—receive my everlaſting love:

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Riſe, my lord, or I inſtantly quit the place. — [Aſide to ſir John.] Can you ſee this unmoved?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Be quiet.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: [Riſing.] Then let this, and this, ſeal my pardon.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: [Running to him.] 'Sdeath, how can you be ſo fooliſh—you would not marry, ſure—don't perſiſt, for if you do you will loſe my friendſhip—Let go her hand, there is witchcraft in the touch.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Then why do you touch it?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I can, with the coldneſs of a philoſopher.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: And would I could—would I were in your ſituation.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: And would I were in your's.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p:
I mean—I mean, my lord, that I perceive your paſſion is a very ſerious one; and yet it is my advice you do not give way to it—do not, for my
ſake—you know my friendſhip for you, and how ſorry I ſhould be to ſee you bound by thoſe ties from which only death can releaſe.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Oh! your old faſhioned opinion of matrimony I begin to deſpiſe.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But I have lately conceived a worſe opinion of it than ever—beſides, while ſhe perſiſts in rejecting your paſſion, you ought to ſubmit; unleſs, in any of your former interviews, ſhe has encouraged your hopes—and in that caſe—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I appeal to his lordſhip's own honour—If I have, ſir, explain.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ay, come, my lord, explain—and I will be judge between you.—What hopes has ſhe ever given you?—I don't mean merely in promiſe, but in manners, looks, ſighs, tears, ſadneſs, joy, or ſorrow?—Come, be particular, or you take from me the power of deciſion.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Why then, to be particular—the firſt time I diſcloſed my paſſion to her, ſhe burſt into a fit of laughter—the ſecond time, ſhe inſiſted on my leaving the room.—But the third time ſhe received me with every mark of kindneſs.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Very well!

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: My dear lord, ſaid ſhe—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Very well!

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: My deareſt creature, cry'd I.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Very well!

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I have, ſaid ſhe, a ſiſter, far more beautiful and amiable than myſelf, to whom I requeſt you will transfer your affection.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Very well! [pleaſed]—and why do you not?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: What! transfer my affection!—never—no— though ſhe try'd to make me jealous.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Did ſhe—of whom?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: That I can't tell—but the ungrateful woman ſwore her heart was engaged, and that nothing could eradicate the fixed and tender affection rooted there for another.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: And can you perſiſt after this, my lord? —for my ſake don't.—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: A paſſion like mine, makes the heart rebellious—it will love on—it will hope, in ſpite of the rules cold reaſon dictates.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I know my uncle is impatient for my return, and therefore I cannot remain any longer here— but I am ſorry to leave you—very ſorry to leave you in this ſituation, indeed, my lord—Now promiſe to get the better of your paſ • on—it will make me much happier if you will.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I can promiſe nothing—why don't you go to your uncle?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I am going—I muſt go, or he'll never pardon it— [aſide.]—Adieu, my lord, for the preſent, and think on my advice— [Aſide, going reluctantly, and turning back to obſerve.] This is the firſt trial of philoſophy.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: By heaven, I begin to ſuſpect what report has told me; that he is the favour'd lover—but ſurely it cannot be—I muſt be more worthy your partiality than he is?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You have your taſte, my lord, and I have mine.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: But reflect upon my birth, my title, my fortune.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh! when a heart gives itſelf away, depend upon it, it never reflects upon the cauſe.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: And is it poſſible you can yield your charms to a cold philoſopher?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: If he is warm to me, his coldneſs upon all other occaſions does me the greater honour—farewel, and believe, that to whom ſo ever I have given my heart, it is gone paſt recal.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p:
What, ſtill ſighing, my lord?—ſtill repeating vows of everlaſting love to one who will not liſten,
but while ſhe holds your heart a captive, inhumanly expoſes you to the deriſion of a rival.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Tell me who that rival is, and my obligations to you will be unbounded.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: If I do tell you, will you promiſe to fight him?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: That is an engagement—I don't like to enter into—and why ſhould you requeſt it?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Becauſe both he and you have offended me, by prefering my ſiſter, and I ſhould like to ſee you engaged in a duel, through pure revenge.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Now I ſuſpect who my rival is—'tis Dorimant—your jealouſy convinces me of it, for I know you love him, and I once thought the affection mutual.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Be not too confident you have found out your rival—you may be miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: But I am ſure I am not—and he is beneath my notice—I ſhall yet win her from him.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: That is impoſſible—becauſe whoever Matilda loves—he is her huſband.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: What! [Starting.] Married!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Yes, married.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Diſtraction!—my hopes for ever gone—my pride, my vanity piqued.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Notwithſtanding your endeavour to conceal it, I ſee vexation painted on your countenance—indeed, my lord, I pity you.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Pity me—that's worſe than the loſs of the woman [Aſide.]—By heaven, if you think I am chagrined, or even diſappointed, you wrong me—I never loved ſeriouſly—do you ſuppoſe I meant to marry?—ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Come, be compoſed.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, madam, I am compoſed— [raiſing his voice.] 'Tis you, and you only, that make me otherwiſe —for here I vow, if I feel a momentary pang, the leaſt ſenſe of ſorrow, it is ſolely in compaſſion to the poor huſband—him I pity, even while I deſpiſe and laugh at him.—Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: And theſe are your real ſentiments.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: My real ſentiments.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: I wiſh ſir John knew them.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Becauſe, from the friendſhip ſir John has for you, and ſuſpecting your love for the lady, as ſoon as he is told of this marriage, he will dread the effect it may have on you.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Then at once to put him out of doubt, I will go and tell him my ſentiments—and we will both laugh at the huſband—ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Do—that is right—now that is juſt right—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: But have I your permiſſion to tell the ſecret to ſir John?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Yes, you have.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Thank you—thank you. I am much obliged to you.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: But you muſt not ſay you heard it from me— nor hint you know who her huſband is—as indeed you don't; for that is a ſecret I gave my word not to reveal.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I underſtand you—you did not abſolutely ſay, but only hinted it was Dorimant—no matter who it is —be it who it will, we will make ſport of him.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: That's right.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Where is ſir John?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: With his uncle at preſent—come, take a few turns in the garden, and when I find you are in a perfect humour to laugh with him. I'll conceive to ſend him to you.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I am very much obliged to you—you are very • ind.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Ay, you can't think how I love to do a good-natured action.

div.head: SCENE II. Another apartment at SIR JOHN's.
div.stage: Enter SIR JOHN and MR. TRADEWELL, following a SERVANT.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p:
My poor father came ſo unexpectedly,
and ſo many miles to ſee me?—Conduct him inſtantly hither.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: What—my unfortunate brother?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Dear uncle, do not behave unkindly to my father, and deſtroy the pleaſure he will take in ſeeing me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: And what 〈◊〉 it to you if I do?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What is it to 〈◊〉 —ſtrange queſtion!— re •• ect what he is to me, and wonder how you can aſk it.

div.stage: Enter MR. CLASSICK, and embraces his ſon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Claſſick.
sp.p: My dear ſon, what pleaſure do I feel in ſeeing and embracing you again—You, the ſole ſupport of my declining years—the ſole prop of my declining ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: [Going up to him.] And what brings you here?

sp.speaker: Mr. Claſſick.
sp.p: Sure I may be permitted to viſit my own ſon, without being called to an account.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: Your viſit, notwithſtanding, might be diſpenſed with— [to ſir John]—he does not come ſo many miles for the pleaſure of ſeeing you—he has ſome new wants to be ſupplied, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Whatever be the motive, his coming gives me pleaſure. [Aſide to Tradewell]—Your behaviour pierces me to the heart.

sp.speaker: Mr. Claſſick.
sp.p: To meet my ſon and my brother both together, is a happineſs unexpected—and ſince it has thus happened, I will enjoy the pleaſure the meeting gives me, without ſuffering the ſeeming unkindneſs of any one to diminiſh it.—Heaven bleſs you both.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: Ay, be liberal of your bleſſings, for you have nothing elſe to beſtow—no other portion to give your ſon.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: And I value them much more than all your inheritance.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p:
Theſe are the precepts of philoſophy. But by our ordinary rules, a father takes care, and provide for his children. Between him and you
the order of nature has been reverſed, for theſe ten years paſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Claſſick.
sp.p: And I glory more to live at his expence, than were he to live at mine—the benefits I receive from him come to me like bleſſings; and their value is doubled by the pleaſure I ſee him take in beſtowing them.—But theſe are ſenſations which your heart is unacquainted with.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: What has made you thus poor?

sp.speaker: Mr. Claſſick.
sp.p: Honour and honeſty.—What has made you thus rich?

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: [Heſitating.] You know I have been for many years a contractor—had I depended on my honour and honeſty, I might have been as poor as you—and with all your contempt of the means of acquiring riches, you have no objection to partake of them—you have ſubmitted to my becoming a father to your ſon, from his infancy; and now, while you, with all your boaſted affection, cannot give him a ſhilling, I am going to marry him to a large fortune, and to ſettle another upon himſelf. Does this wound your delicacy?

sp.speaker: Mr. Claſſick.
sp.p: No—it almoſt makes me weep in gratitude—but to whom are you going to marry him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: She's the daughter of my wife.

sp.speaker: Mr. Claſſick.
sp.p: I rejoice at ſuch an alliance.—Come, brother, let theſe approaching nuptials unite us all in love and friendſhip; forget our frivolous differences, for in my heart I am grateful and affectionate.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Some obſtacles may prevent the marriage.

sp.speaker: Mr. Claſſick.
sp.p: Oh no—it has no doubt been planned with too much care.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: Brother, it is one of the beſt contracts I ever made.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But allow me time, ſir, to gain the lady's heart.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: A lady's heart may be gained in a day—ſometimes in an hour.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Not ſuch a heart as I would poſſeſs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: Well—I'll give you eight days—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: That is too ſhort a time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: Not too ſhort to win eight hundred women—I wiſh I had a contract for as many as I myſelf could win in that time—and by ſending them to the ladies I have no doubt but I might encreaſe my fortune half a million.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: How much ſoever I may dread your reſentment, ſir, I muſt declare I cannot marry at preſent.

sp.speaker: Mr. Claſſick.
sp.p: Reflect, my ſon.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I do reflect, but 'tis too late.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p:
If ye belong to me—but no—it is to him you belong—and him you are like—had you been mine, then you might have been like me, complying, obedient, amiable, and gentle—but till you prove yourſelf ſo, I have done with you—nor will I give ſixpence to a man, who does not look up to me as a pattern and model for all his action •
▪

sp.speaker: Mr. Claſſick.
sp.p:
Follow 〈◊〉
▪ my ſon, and promiſe to obey with chearfulneſs—he has virtues you ſhould reſpect—you have obligations which are binding—and this propoſed marriage beyond any other.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Oh heavens!

sp.speaker: Mr. Claſſick.
sp.p: What is the matter?—Where is your uſual joy on ſeeing me?—perhaps my coming has diſpleaſed you—if ſo, ſeek no excuſes but let me go away, and come another time, when y • u •• pect me.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Expect you—Muſt I ex •• ct your coming, to form my features in a ſmile to meet you?—No— your preſence always gives me joy, no preparation could put on.

sp.speaker: Mr. Claſſick.
sp.p: I believe you.—But why thus melancholy?—This intented marriage is perhaps the cauſe of your uneaſineſs.—Come, acknowledge your affections are placed upon ſome other.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: They are.

sp.speaker: Mr. Claſſick.
sp.p: Perhaps they are bound by ſome engagement?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Mr. Claſſick.
sp.p: I am ſorry for it—but go on—I commend you—Who is the object of your love?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: My wife.—

sp.speaker: Mr. Claſſick.
sp.p: Your wife!—Are you then married?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Yes—I conſulted affection, and not ambition, and have therefore concealed my marriage; leſt the world, as well as you, ſhould blame me for it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Claſſick.
sp.p: Is your wife prudent?—Is ſhe ſuch as you wiſhed to find her?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: She is.

sp.speaker: Mr. Claſſick.
sp.p: Then you have made an excellent match.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: This kindneſs conſoles, and makes me leſs unhappy.

sp.speaker: Mr. Claſſick.
sp.p: Where is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Here in this houſe, accompanied by her ſiſter, and another lady, who paſſes for her relation, and the miſtreſs of the houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Claſſick.
sp.p: We m ••• think of ſome expedient to divert your uncle's attention for the preſent, and during the delay we may contrive ſome means to declare your marriage with ſafety.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But the idea of the event being divulged, after having thus long concealed it, makes me all confuſion—ſooner or later I ſhall get the better of this ſtrange humour—but at preſent I cannot ſuppreſs the ſhame I feel, leſt the world ſhould know I am married.

sp.speaker: Mr. Claſſick.
sp.p: Do not be aſhamed of a good woman —you philoſophers are ever ſearching after novelty, and what could you ſhow the world more worthy their attention than a good wife?—In all your reſearches, my ſon, nothing could ſo well eſtabliſh yours, and your children's fame. What are plants and minerals?—Improve human nature, that is the firſt great work of a philoſopher.

div.head: SCENE I. An apartment at SIR JOHN's.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Where ſhall I hide me, from my uncle's ſolicitations?—Where hide me from my own reflections? —Oh! that I could but ſhake off this idle fear of the world, and own I am married.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, [laughing] ha, ha, ha, ha, ha—Oh! I ſhall die—I ſhall never recover it.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: [Alarmed.] What's the matter?—What are you laughing at?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: At the ſight of you.—Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: [More alarmed ſtill.] At the ſight of me?—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I have ſuch a ſecret to tell you—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: [Earneſtly.] What is it?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: It concerns Matilda.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: [Starting.] Indeed?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: And does it concern any body elſe?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: It does—But you'll keep it a ſecret?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Depend upon me—What is it?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: [Whiſpering.] Matilda is married.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: [Starting.] You don't ſay ſo?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: She is, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: You don't ſay ſo?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I do.—She is married.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But do you know to whom?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: No—But I gueſs.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I gueſs it is to Dorimant.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: [Aſide] Thank heaven!

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: [Overhearing him.] Why do you thank heaven?—Are you glad ſhe is married?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: No, my lord, very ſorry, I aſſure you!— I would give a good deal ſhe was not—And you, I ſuppoſe, are deeply concerned too.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha—Do you imagine I meant to marry her?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: [Angrily.] You ſaid ſo before me, ſir.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: But that was after ſhe had declared her heart engaged, and I knew ſhe would not accept my offer.— I marry!—I marry!—I become a huſband!—I be made the fool of a woman!—No, no, no.—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: S'death!— [In great agitation]—And yet wiſer men than you have married.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: But none ſo wiſe as you; and it is my ambition to be in every thing as wiſe as you.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Who has informed you of this ſecret?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: That I muſt not ſay—nor ſhall I let Matilda know I am acquainted with it; but redouble my aſſiduities, ſtill urging her to what I know ſhe cannot accept: and thus, in time, ſoften that heart which, in time, will harden to all the inſipid attentions of a huſband.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But have you no reſpect for him?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—Reſpect for a huſband!—Had you ever any?—Whoever he is, don't you deſpiſe him? —But why don't you laugh?—You won't laugh?— You uſed to laugh on theſe occaſions.—What a ſolemn countenance!—S'death—I beg pardon, ſir John—Indeed I do.—But a thought this moment ſtrikes me.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Nay, perhaps I wrong you—and yet the perſon who told me this ſecret had ſome doubts who the huſband was—and upon my ſoul (forgive me if I am miſtaken) by your ſtrange, awkward manner, and melancholy countenance, ſomething tells me—perhaps you are he?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I am he, ſir.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: "No, you don't ſay ſo!"—"You don't ſay "ſo?"—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Confuſion!

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Yes—I ſee it is true—that is the very gait of a married man—How ſtrange, I could not perceive it before.—But, my dear ſir John, pray forgive my having laughed—Upon my honour, had I known, had I conceived you had been the huſband, I would not have laughed before your face.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Refrain from it now then.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I will—And as I know no better method, than by quitting your preſence—I take my leave.— [Going—returns.]—But before I go, can I mediate between you and your uncle, or you and your father?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: To the world, however, you may depend upon it, I will paint the circumſtance in the moſt favourable light—I will ſay, your falling in love was but a weakneſs attendant on human nature—your ſhame of owning it; but—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: My lord, my lord, you'll make me forget myſelf.—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Sir John, ſir John, you have forgot yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Leave this room, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I will— [goes, and returns.]—and I'll ſend your wife to you.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: How painful is my ſituation!—Shall then the object that was to have beſtowed happineſs on me, be the ſole cauſe of all my miſery?—
My reſolution is fixed; nor do you, Dorimant, attempt to ſhake it.—I leave London this day, never to ſee that, or lady Claſſick more.

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: Sure you have loſt your ſenſes!—What will the world ſay of you then?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: When I am away, that will be indifferent.

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: But your wife, Matilda—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: She has been the cauſe of all—And having had the pleaſure of telling the ſecret ſhe has a huſband, ſhe may now have the pleaſure of telling the ſecret ſhe has none.

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: You cannot be in earneſt?—She will not ſubmit to a ſeparation.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: She muſt.—Who's there?
Deſire her—her ladyſhip, to come hither.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: [Surpriſed.] Who, ſir?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Lady Claſſick—my wife.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, which of the ladies is that?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Do you not know?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Yes, ſir—But I thought I was not to know.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Even this fellow is laughing at me.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: No, upon my word, ſir—Ha, ha, ha!— No, indeed, ſir—Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: See what I am come to!

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: Would I were married to Emily, as you are to Matilda!—And I have hopes my wiſh will be very ſoon accompliſhed: for I have juſt received intelligence I may aſſume my real name, and put an end to every objection ſhe has conceived to me.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Oh! here comes my wife—I am agitated —I dread to tell her what I know ſhe will be concerned to hear.

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: Why then have you determined ſo raſhly?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Can I ſtay, and expoſe myſelf to the reproaches of my uncle?—To the jeſts of the town?—But will you, Dorimant, endeavour to find my father, and tell him my determinations—aud tell him alſo—

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: To perſuade you to alter them—That I ſhall certainly tell him.

div.stage: Enter LADY CLASSICK, EMILY, and LUCY.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I am glad you have brought company with you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: My dear ſir John, is it your uncle who is the cauſe of this ſeeming uneaſineſs?—Tell me if it is—and put an end to my anxiety.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Your ladyſhip's anxiety may now entirely ceaſe—The wiſh of your heart is fulfilled—Our marriage is publicly known—I am congratulated every moment by one friend or other—and it is to you, ladies, I am under the obligation.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I had been inſincere, could I have denied the pride it gave me to be ſuppoſed your wife—but if ever that pride tempted me to drop a hint—except to the marquis—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: And I call heaven to witneſs, I never breathed a ſyllable of it, except to half a dozen of my moſt intimate friends, and people whom I knew would be as particular not to mention it, as I myſelf would be.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: And I wiſh I may not ſtay another hour in my lady's ſervice, if I ever told it to a ſingle ſoul except mrs. Fringe, the milliner, and mr. Puff, the hairdreſſer; and I am ſure they never mentioned it again, for they promiſed me they would not.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: No more of this—I have done with my accuſations—I have done with you all, too.—I leave London this night, and it will be ſome time before you hear from me.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh heaven! I cannot ſurvive this.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Are you not known to be my wife?— What more would you require?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Require, my huſband?—not to be thus abandoned—left unprotected.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I ſhall leave you in the care of my father; and he will protect you from the inſults of my uncle.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But who is to protect me from the inſults of the world?—Protect me from that fixed affection rooted in my heart for you?—And from the remembrance of your unkindneſs?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Could you live with me in the retreat that I ſhall fly to?—Could you quit the pleaſures of the world?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: To me, the pleaſures of the world can only be where you are▪

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: I am out of all patience—Oh! that you were but my huſband?

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: As I went out, ſir John, I met your uncle and your father, both returning—and your uncle communicated to me a project he means immediately to put into execution.—He has been informed of your marriage, that it took place abroad, and without all the due forms to render it legal—He therefore means to annul it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh heavens!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Annul my marriage?—Let him—then openly, and in the face of day, I'll marry her again.— [Going, and taking her hand.]—Annul my marriage?— Make void the happieſt action of my life?—An act which gave to my gloomy mind a friend, a ſoothing partner to reform it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Is this my huſband?—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Yes—but, in the fear of loſing you, a lover ſtill.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Now, would you were my huſband in good earneſt!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What ceremonies were wanting.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Indeed, ſir, I don't think the parſon or you forgot one.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: And pray what ſaid my father to my uncle's propoſal?

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: At firſt he pleaded for your union to be acknowledged; but upon your uncle declaring, that on thoſe terms he would diſinherit you, he appeared to ſubmit.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I will go to them immediately, and my uncle ſhall find—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Wait till his reſentment may, in ſome meaſure, be abated!—Oh! for me to be the cauſe of your ruin!—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Retire, my love, and do not appear till I ſend for you—But remain in full confidence, that if I give way to my paſſion, it is for your ſake—or if I ſuppreſs it, it is ſtill for you.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: This ſituation, in ſpite of myſelf, makes me compaſſionate them both—and in ſpite of myſelf, it makes me long to be married.

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: I ſhould hope I cauſed that deſire more than any thing elſe.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: You?

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: Yes—and when you are my wife—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: I your wife?—I ſhould be glad to ſee it!

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: I know you would—and ſo ſhould I.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: I marry a man without family or fortune!

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: Sir John is my witneſs—I have both— enquire of him, and be convinced.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Dear lady, I this moment parted from mr. Tradewell Claſſick, and he aſſures me he is going to ſet aſide your ſiſter's marriage.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Very true, my lord—and this is the time for you—a woman diſconſolate and forſaken.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: But ſhe ſhan't be forſaken; in ſpite of all I may have ſaid, I have a great mind to go and offer myſelf to her again.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: And if you do, my lord, I'll anſwer for the event.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: You adviſe me, then.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: I do—for it will give me great pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: [Bowing.] You are very good—you are, upon all occaſions, my good friend—You firſt diſcovered to me the marriage, though you could not tell me with whom—and then, unfortunately, you ſent me to laugh at the very man himſelf.

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: How then can you offer yourſelf on the preſent occaſion? for he, no doubt, has told her what you ſaid.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: No matter, his lordſhip can unſay it—he can go and proteſt to ſir John, what he ſaid was the mere effect of reſentment; for that while he laughed, he was ready to cry.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: If I thought ſuch an acknowledgment would have any effect—

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Depend upon it, it will have great effect.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Where is ſir John?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: I believe, at preſent, with my ſiſter—go, go, make atonement.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: You will anſwer for my reception?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: That I will.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Thank you—thank you—and I think I can anſwer for it myſelf.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Sir John deſerves this recompence.

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: But I doubt it is leſs in recompence to ſir John, than in ſpleen to his lordſhip.

div.stage: Enter MR. CLASSICK and MR. T. CLASSICK.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: Oh the great ſcholar, that could not learn to live ſingle a few years—the great philoſopher, who ſcorns to underſtand the value of money: nor from me ſhall he ever know the comforts of it; for I diſinherit him, but upon one condition—unleſs he conſents to declare his marriage invalid.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: [Coming forward.] Abandon a wife whom he has ſworn to love and protect!—and who is to forgive you for making ſuch a propoſal?

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: Oh! your humble ſervant, madam —What, you are the pretended wife, I ſuppoſe?—you are the lady who has enſnared him?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Enſnare—enſnare a man with his head fortified with Latin and Greek, and his heart made hard with philoſophy.—You might as well ſuppoſe a poor honeſt tradeſman could enſnare a rich, hardened contractor.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: Here's a vixen—reflecting on the means by which I have acquired my riches—But let me tell you, madam, my nephew's marriage is an illegal one, and I will take care to make you both aſhamed of it.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: In that caſe, we cannot retaliate, for I ſuppoſe there is not any thing you would be aſhamed of.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: Is this the gentle ſpirit you deſcribed to me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Claſſick.
sp.p: Such was the character I received— but give me leave to ſay, madam, you have departed from it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: Oh what a bargain the great man has made.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Not ſo good a bargain as ſome of yours have been.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: But while he acknowledges this woman, his crime ſhall be his puniſhment—I will no longer be his banker. Let him apply to his ſtudies—a philoſopher can extract gold from baſe metal.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: And a contractor can extract it, from every thing that comes in his way.

sp.speaker: Mr. Claſſick.
sp.p: Let us be gone, brother.

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: Be patient, gentlemen, for I aſſure you this lady is not the wife of ſir John.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: I know ſhe is not—and I'll have it proved.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: [To Dorimant.] And do you pretend to ſay ſir John is not lawfully married?

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: No—I did not ſay that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: How, ſir, do you contradict yourſelf? Pray were you the witneſs to a legal marriage?

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: I was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: •• ere, you ſee ſhe has brought him over [To Claſſick.]—this man I have often ſeen at ſir John's, is, I dare ſay, ſome poor relation, or ſome attorney.—I'll put him to the proof— [To Dorimant, aſide.]—Hark you, ſir, do you mean to be a witneſs on the trial, and ſwear ſhe is the lawful wife of my nephew?—Here, take this purſe— [gives it to him.]—and tell me now, what will you ſwear?

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: What do you wiſh me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: That, that lady is not my nephew's lawful wife.

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: I will ſwear it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: And keep your countenance?

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: And keep my countenance.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: You are cleverer than I thought you—a perfect man of buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: But I'll ſwear it without your purſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: He is no attorney after all.

div.stage: Enter LORD LOVEMORE, and goes to EMILY.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Do you know I have made myſelf ridiculous!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Is that poſſible?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: They both laughed at me.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: And why did you not laugh again?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I did—but that did not prevent their laughing on.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: [Going to him.] I can tell you what, ſir—notwithſtanding the trick you have played me, I am going to do you a kind turn for it.—I am going to take your wife from you; and you ſhould be obliged to me, for taking away ſuch a termagant—She has treated me—

sp.speaker: Mr. Claſſick.
sp.p: It is true—She has treated your uncle in a manner unworthy the woman you ſhould love.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: My wife?—It cannot be!—

div.stage: Enter LADY CLASSICK, SIR JOHN meets her, and takes her hand.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Here is my father and my uncle, who both accuſe you of treating them with diſreſpect—Is it poſſible my Matilda can deſerve ſuch a charge?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: In aſpiring to be yours, I own my offence— but in no one circumſtance elſe, has even my heart, much leſs my lips, preſumed to offend—nor had I ever, till this moment, the confuſion to appear before either of them.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p:
But I, knowing the cruel deſign of theſe
gentlemen, took the liberty to repreſent my ſiſter, and behaved on the occaſion as ſhe ought to do.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: [To mr. Claſſick.] In what do I merit the ſeverity I am threatened with?—In having complied with the deſires of a beloved ſon, can I be the object of his father's reſentment?

sp.speaker: Mr. Claſſick.
sp.p: In you, madam, I approve my ſon's choice, nor would have it changed, had he the power to make you happy. But without the concurrence of his uncle, you muſt live in poverty, and his determination is fixed.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: [To mr. Tradewell.] To you, ſir, I have nothing to offer in my behalf, except my tears, my heart-wounding ſorrows.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: I refuſe thoſe offers.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Accept, then, my ſubmiſſion. To have gained your approbation I would have knelt and ſupplicated; but as that muſt not be—ſuffer me to kneel and plead for a nephew, to whom you have ever been indulgent— Let me not be the cauſe of his misfortunes—Pardon him —take him to your heart again—and, hard as the taſk is, I conſent never to ſee him more.

sp.speaker: Mr. Claſſick.
sp.p: What's the matter, brother?—You heſitate.—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Dear uncle, if you feel the leaſt ray of pity—

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: For the firſt time in my life, I do.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Then cheriſh it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tradewell.
sp.p: [After a pauſe, as ſtruggling with his inclination.] I will—and give my conſent that you ſhall cheriſh your wife.— [Gives her to him.]—And yet I cannot but be ſorry ſhe was not like her [pointing to Emily] that when ſhe knelt, I might have thrown her from me—But as it is—as it is— [struggling]—I can't help forgiving her.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Oh! my Matilda! who can doubt your power?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p:
Since ſhe has proved it there— [pointing to Tradewell.]—What's the matter, my lord?—You look
concern'd?—Can't you, as uſual, laugh at your diſappointment?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha— [affecting to laugh—he ſtops ſhort.]—No—I can't laugh ſo well as I did—And I believe it would be much eaſier for me to ſhed a few tears.

sp.speaker: Dorimant.
sp.p: Nay, my lord, for once, if poſſible, forget your diſappointment, and partake the joy of your friends.—My happineſs is ſuperlative, for Emily has juſt conſented to be mine.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I have been an impoſtor—for while I could equivocate with my friend, and bluſh at being the huſband of ſuch a wife as this, I uſurped, like many others, the title of philoſopher, without having a claim to it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Claſſick.
sp.p: And believe me, my ſon, while you fill the ſtation as you ought to do, no title is more honourable than that of A MARRIED MAN.
